In this problem, we will determine the present value of the projected cash flows in four years if the appropriate discount rate is 9% compounded quarterly.

We must consider the table given.

First, to solve the present value of the cash flows, we must identify the effective annual rate or APR. The problem provides us the stated rate or the APR rate of 9% compounded quarterly; hence we will use this rate and compound period to determine the effective annual rate.

Effective Annual Rate refers to a loan's annual interest rate after considering the nominal interest and the compounding period. The EAR calculation considers the APR and the compounding period of a loan. Hence, the EAR can be calculated using the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{EAR} &=\left(1+\dfrac{APR}{m}\right)^m-1
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$APR$, which refers to the annual percentage rate\
$m$, which refers to the compounding period

Now let's calculate the effective annual rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{EAR} &=\left(1+\dfrac{0.09}{4}\right)^4-1
\\[10pt]
 &=1.093083319-1
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{{9.3\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, we will consider the rate of 9.3% in determining the present value of cash flows.

Next, to calculate the present value of each cash flows, we will consider the 9.3% effective annual rate from the previous steps. Each period's future value refers to the projected cash flow, and the period is their respective year.

The present value can be calculated using the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present Value} &=\sum\dfrac{{FV}_{t}}{\left(1 + r\right)^{t}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which refers to the cash flow

$t$, which represent the period

$r$, which indicate the discount rate
